Section 16 More complicated integrals

¶

We continue our work on integration by introducing exponential and logarithmic functions, as well as those involving compositions.

Subsection 16.1 Exponential and logarithmic functions

¶

We have learned a lot of techniques of differentiation. We will only learn how to undo a few of these, such as those derivatives involving \(e^x\text{,}\) \(\ln(x)\text{,}\) and the chain rule. For example, we omit the method required to undo derivatives computed with the product rule.

Recall from our earlier work that \(\displaystyle\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(e^x\right) = e^x\) and \(\displaystyle\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\ln(x)\right) = \dfrac{1}{x}\text{.}\)

What consequences do these facts have when we approach this problem from integration? Our new approach is to ask what (unknown) function has a derivative that matches the integrand? rather than to ask what is the derivative of the (known) function? In other words, where did this derivative come from?

Fact 16.1.

Since the indefinite integral undoes the action of the derivative, we have

\begin{equation*} \int e^x\,dx = e^x + c \end{equation*}

and

\begin{equation*} \int \dfrac{1}{x}\,dx = \ln(|x|) + c \end{equation*}
Example 16.2. Basic indefinite integral: I.

Compute \(\displaystyle \int 3e^x + \dfrac{1}{x} + x^2 dx\text{.}\)

Example 16.3. Basic indefinite integral: II.

Compute \(\displaystyle \int \dfrac{2}{x} + \dfrac{1}{4}e^x + \dfrac{1}{x^4} dx\text{.}\)

Example 16.4. Introduction to \(u\)-substitution.

Compute \(\int 15e^{5x}\, dx\text{.}\) Taking the derivative of what function gives us \(f(x) = 15e^{5x}\text{?}\)

Fact 16.5. Undoing differentiation by the Chain Rule.
\begin{equation*} \dfrac{d}{dx}\left((f \circ g)(x)\right) = \dfrac{d}{dx}\left((f(g(x))\right) = \dfrac{df}{dg}\dfrac{dg}{dx} \end{equation*}

Subsection 16.2 \(u\)-substitution

¶

Some words.

Before we begin, we need a brief definition.

Definition 16.6.

For \(u = g(x)\text{,}\) the differential is defined as

\begin{equation*} du = g'(x) dx \end{equation*}
Algorithm 16.7. Integration by Substitution.

This is often called \(u\)-substitution since we think of \(u\) as the name assigned to the inside function \(g(x)\) from the Chain Rule. To outline the method we will think of integrating with respect to the variable \(x\text{,}\) though where you see an \(x\) below you can imagine another variable such as \(t\text{.}\)

  1. Define a new variable, called \(u = g(x)\text{,}\) as some function of the old variable \(x\text{.}\)

  2. Compute the differential \(du = g'(x) dx\text{.}\)

  3. Put everything in the integral in terms of the new variable, \(u\text{.}\) (Replace the inside function by the letter u and replace what remains by the definition for \(du\text{.}\)) Sometimes we have to rearrange a bit here so that du fits back in the integral.

  4. Try to integrate in terms of the new variable, \(u\text{.}\)

  5. After integrating, try to put everything back in terms of the old variable \(x\text{.}\)

Example 16.8.

Find \(\displaystyle \int 2xe^{x^2}\,dx\text{.}\)

Example 16.9.

Find \(\displaystyle \int \dfrac{e^{3t}}{1+e^{3t}}\,dt\text{.}\)

Remark 16.10. Warning.

Integration by substitution does not always work!

Example 16.11.

Try (but only briefly) to find \(\displaystyle \int 2x^2e^{x^2}\,dx\text{.}\)

Example 16.12. Sturgeon growth rate.

The growth of female Atlantic sturgeon (fish) in the Hudson River, New York, approximately follows the differential equation

\begin{equation*} \dfrac{dL}{dt} = 19.56e^{0.074t} \end{equation*}

with \(L(0) = 14.65\) (age in yr, length in cm, measured from hatching). Solve this differential equation.

Example 16.13. Sturgeon growth rate.

Female sturgeon mature and begin to reproduce when they are roughly \(191\) cm long. How long does it take the female sturgeon to mature?

Exercises 16.3 Quick Practice

1.

Compute \(\int 3e^{7x}\, dx\text{.}\)

2.
Compute \(\int \frac{1}{2x}\, dx\text{.}\)
3.
Compute \(\int 3e^{7x} + \dfrac{1}{2x}+x^2\, dx\text{.}\)
4.
In a \(u\)-substitution problem, if \(u = f(x) = 3x^2 + 2x\text{,}\) what is \(du\text{?}\)
